Now that we have made the formal definition above, we are in a position to prove the formula for calculating a binomial coefficient. The argument, is essentially, an application of more clever counting.


Proposition

We can evaluate the binomial coefficient 'n choose r' as \[ \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!} = {n\choose r} \]

Solution

Let \(S\) be the set \(S = \{1,2,3,\dots, n\}\). Let us count the possible arrangements of \(S\) in a clever manner.

  1. Choose a subset of \(S\) with \(r\) elements call it T. By definition there are \({n}\choose{r}\) choices for T.
  2. Choose an arrangement of \(T\), by above, the number of arrangements is \(r!\).
  3. Choose an arrangement of the remaining elements of S. There are \(n-r\) remaining elements so there are \((n-r)!\) different arrangements.
  4. Note that the number of arrangements of \(S\) is \(n!\).

The total number of arrangements of \(S\) has to be equal to the product of all the arrangements of the subsets we have chosen above hence \[ n! = r! \times (n-r)! \times {n\choose r}. \] Rearranging this equation we get that < \[ \frac{n!}{r!(n-r)!} = {n \choose r}, \] and so the proof is complete.
